{{Taxobox | image = Corellanus.jpg | image_caption = | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Cortinariaceae]] | genus = ''[[Cortinarius]]'' | species = '''''C. orellanus''''' | binomial = ''Cortinarius orellanus'' | binomial_authority = [[Elias Magnus Fries|Fries]], 1838 |synonyms = ''Cortinarius rutilans'' [[Lucien Quélet|Quél.]]
''Dermocybe orellana'' (Fr.) [[Adalbert Ricken|Ricken]] }} {{mycomorphbox |name=''Cortinarius orellanus'' |whichGills=adnate |capShape=flat |hymeniumType=gills |stipeCharacter=ring |ecologicalType=mycorrhizal |sporePrintColor=reddish-brown |howEdible=deadly }} '''''Cortinarius orellanus''''', commonly known as the '''fools webcap''', is a species of deadly fungus in the family [[Cortinariaceae]] native to Europe. Within the genus it belongs to a group known as the [[Orellani]], all of which are highly toxic—eating them results in [[kidney failure]], which is often irreversible. The mushroom is generally tan to brown all over. ==Taxonomy== ''C. orellanus'' was first described by Swedish mycologist [[Elias Magnus Fries]] in his 1838 book ''Epicrisis Systematis Mycologici seu Synopsis Hymenomycetum''.{{cite book |last=Fries |first=E. M. |year=1838 |title=Epicrisis Systematis Mycologici: Seu Synopsis Hymenomycetum |language=Latin |trans-title=A Critical Study of Mycology: A Synopsis of the Hymenomycetes |publisher=Regiae Academiae Typographia |location=Uppsala, Sweden |volume=1–2 |page=288 |url=http://www.librifungorum.org/Image.asp?ItemID=634&ImageFileName=0288b.jpg}} It is one of seven highly toxic species that make up the [[orellani]], a subgenus within genus ''Cortinarius''.{{cite journal |last=Gasparini |first=B. |year=2004 |title=''Cortinarius'' subgenus ''Orellani'' in Australia and in the world |journal=Australasian Mycologist |volume=23 |issue=2 |pages=62–76 |url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/86d4e0_8dc7de09f7b74fb28367b59a29975599.pdf |format=PDF}} ==Description== ''Cortinarius orellanus'' has a concave [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of {{convert|3|to|6|cm|in|frac=4}} diameter, though rare specimens reach {{convert|8|cm|in|frac=4}} across. The cap flattens with age. In colour, it is an orange-brown, and is covered in fine, fibrous scales but become smooth with age. The cap surface turns black with potassium hydroxide. The thick [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are light ochre-coloured, changing to a rust-brown with age as the spores mature. They have an [[Lamella (mycology)#Classification|adnate or sinuate]] connection to the stipe. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|4|to|9|cm|in|frac=4}} tall, and {{convert|1|to|2|cm|in|frac=8}} thick with a tapering base. It is the same colour or slightly paler than the cap, and is yellowish at the top. There are occasionally fragments of the pale yellow veil (cortina) attached to its lower half. The firm [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is pale ochre. It smells slightly of radishes when cut and has no strong taste.{{Cite book |last1=Bresinsky |first1=A. |last2=Besl |first2=H. |year=2004 |title=A Colour Atlas of Poisonous Fungi: A Handbook for Pharmacists, Doctors, and Biologists |publisher=CRC Press x |isbn=9780723415763 |pages=53–54 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EIcQGsZ2kksC&pg=PA54}} ==Distribution and habitat== ''Cortinarius orellanus'' occurs in central and eastern Europe (Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia), though is rare in Germany. It is occasionally found in southern Britain. It grows in deciduous forests under beech, hornbeam and oak, often near pine trees. ==Toxicity== The danger of ''C. orellanus'' was uncovered in 1957, after (in 1952) 102 people fell ill after eating it in [[Bydgoszcz]], Poland. Eleven of the victims died. Since then, cases of poisoning have been recorded in France, Switzerland, and Germany.{{cite journal |last1=Prast |first1=H. |last2=Werner |first2=E. R. |last3=Pfaller |first3=W. |last4=Moser |first4=M. |year=1988 |title=Toxic properties of the mushroom Cortinarius orellanus |journal=Archives of Toxicology |doi=10.1007/BF00316263 |volume=62 |issue=1 |pages=81–88}} In 1997, four people suffered [[Nephrotoxicity|renal toxicity]] after mistaking ''C. orellanus'' for the edible and prized [[chanterelle]] in Austria, where wild mushroom picking is popular.{{cite journal |last1=Horn |first1=S. |last2=Horina |first2=J. H. |last3=Krejs |first3=G. J. |last4=Holzer |first4=H. |last5=Ratschek |first5=M. |year=1997 |title=End-stage renal failure from mushroom poisoning with ''Cortinarius orellanus'': Report of four cases and review of the literature |journal=American Journal of Kidney Diseases |doi=10.1016/S0272-6386(97)90066-4 |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=282–86}} The relevant toxin is [[orellanine]].{{cite journal |last1=Richard |first1=Jean-Michel |last2=Louis |first2=Josette |last3=Cantin |first3=Danielle |date=1 March 1988 |title=Nephrotoxicity of orellanine, a toxin from the mushroom ''Cortinarius orellanus'' |journal=Archives of Toxicology |issn=0340-5761 |doi=10.1007/BF00570151 |volume=62 |issue=2–3 |pages=242–245 }} ==See also== * [[List of deadly fungus species]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IndexFungorum|158559}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q1367003}} [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Cortinarius|orellanus]] [[Category:Deadly fungi]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1838]] [[Category:Taxa named by Elias Magnus Fries]]
